trans-unit.source: Traffic Manager Monitoring
trans-unit.target: Traffic Manager Monitoring

trans-unit.source: This article will help undertstand and configure Traffic Manager monitoring
trans-unit.target: This article will help undertstand and configure Traffic Manager monitoring

trans-unit.source: About Traffic Manager Monitoring
trans-unit.target: About Traffic Manager Monitoring

trans-unit.source: Azure Traffic Manager monitors your endpoints, including cloud services and websites, to ensure they are available.
trans-unit.target: Azure Traffic Manager monitors your endpoints, including cloud services and websites, to ensure they are available.

trans-unit.source: In order for monitoring to work correctly, you must set it up the same way for every endpoint that you specify in your Traffic Manager profile.
trans-unit.target: In order for monitoring to work correctly, you must set it up the same way for every endpoint that you specify in your Traffic Manager profile.

trans-unit.source: After you configure monitoring, Traffic Manager will display the status for your endpoints and profile in the Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: After you configure monitoring, Traffic Manager will display the status for your endpoints and profile in the Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: You can configure monitoring settings in the Management Portal on the Configure page for your Traffic Manager profile.
trans-unit.target: You can configure monitoring settings in the Management Portal on the Configure page for your Traffic Manager profile.

trans-unit.source: You can specify the following settings:
trans-unit.target: You can specify the following settings:

trans-unit.source: **Protocol** – Choose HTTP or HTTPS.
trans-unit.target: **Protocol** – Choose HTTP or HTTPS.

trans-unit.source: It’s important to note that HTTPS monitoring does not verify whether your SSL certificate is valid, it only checks that certificate is present.
trans-unit.target: It’s important to note that HTTPS monitoring does not verify whether your SSL certificate is valid, it only checks that certificate is present.

trans-unit.source: **Port** – Choose the port used for the request.
trans-unit.target: **Port** – Choose the port used for the request.

trans-unit.source: Standard HTTP and HTTPS ports are among the choices.
trans-unit.target: Standard HTTP and HTTPS ports are among the choices.

trans-unit.source: **Relative path and file name** – Give the path and the name of the file that the monitoring system will attempt to access.
trans-unit.target: **Relative path and file name** – Give the path and the name of the file that the monitoring system will attempt to access.

trans-unit.source: Note that a forward slash "/" is a valid entry for the relative path and implies that the file is in the root directory (default).
trans-unit.target: Note that a forward slash "/" is a valid entry for the relative path and implies that the file is in the root directory (default).

trans-unit.source: About monitoring health status
trans-unit.target: About monitoring health status

trans-unit.source: Azure Traffic Manager displays profile and endpoint service health in the Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: Azure Traffic Manager displays profile and endpoint service health in the Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: The status column for both the profile and the endpoint displays the most recent monitor status.
trans-unit.target: The status column for both the profile and the endpoint displays the most recent monitor status.

trans-unit.source: You can use this status to understand the health of your profiles according to your Traffic Manager monitoring settings.
trans-unit.target: You can use this status to understand the health of your profiles according to your Traffic Manager monitoring settings.

trans-unit.source: When your profile is healthy, DNS queries will be distributed to your services based on the traffic routing settings for the profile (Round Robin, Performance, or Failover).
trans-unit.target: When your profile is healthy, DNS queries will be distributed to your services based on the traffic routing settings for the profile (Round Robin, Performance, or Failover).

trans-unit.source: Once the Traffic Manager monitoring system detects a change in monitor status, it updates the status entry in the Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: Once the Traffic Manager monitoring system detects a change in monitor status, it updates the status entry in the Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: It can take up to five minutes for the state change to refresh.
trans-unit.target: It can take up to five minutes for the state change to refresh.

trans-unit.target: Endpoint Monitor status

trans-unit.target: Disabled

trans-unit.target: Enabled

trans-unit.target: The status of at least one endpoint is “Degraded”.

trans-unit.target: Degraded

trans-unit.target: This is a flag that customer action is required.

trans-unit.target: Enabled

trans-unit.target: The status of at least one endpoint is “Online”.

trans-unit.target: No endpoints are “Degraded”.

trans-unit.target: Online

trans-unit.target: The service is accepting traffic and customer action is not required.

trans-unit.source: CheckingEndpoints
trans-unit.target: CheckingEndpoints

trans-unit.target: Transition state.

trans-unit.source: This typically occurs when a profile has just been enabled and the endpoint health is being probed.
trans-unit.target: This typically occurs when a profile has just been enabled and the endpoint health is being probed.

trans-unit.target: Enabled

trans-unit.source: The status of all endpoints defined in the profile is either “Disabled” or “Stopped”, or the profile has no defined endpoints.
trans-unit.target: The status of all endpoints defined in the profile is either “Disabled” or “Stopped”, or the profile has no defined endpoints.

trans-unit.source: Inactive
trans-unit.target: Inactive

trans-unit.source: No endpoints are active, but the profile is still enabled.
trans-unit.target: No endpoints are active, but the profile is still enabled.

trans-unit.source: How monitoring works
trans-unit.target: How monitoring works

trans-unit.source: An example timeline illustrating the monitoring process with a single cloud service is displayed is below.
trans-unit.target: An example timeline illustrating the monitoring process with a single cloud service is displayed is below.

trans-unit.source: This scenario shows the following:
trans-unit.target: This scenario shows the following:

trans-unit.source: The cloud service is available and receiving traffic via this Traffic Manager profile ONLY.
trans-unit.target: The cloud service is available and receiving traffic via this Traffic Manager profile ONLY.

trans-unit.source: The cloud service becomes unavailable.
trans-unit.target: The cloud service becomes unavailable.

trans-unit.source: The cloud service remains unavailable for a time much longer than the DNS Time-to-Live (TTL).
trans-unit.target: The cloud service remains unavailable for a time much longer than the DNS Time-to-Live (TTL).

trans-unit.source: The cloud service becomes available again.
trans-unit.target: The cloud service becomes available again.

trans-unit.source: The cloud service resumes receiving traffic via this Traffic Manager profile ONLY.
trans-unit.target: The cloud service resumes receiving traffic via this Traffic Manager profile ONLY.

trans-unit.source: Traffic Manager Monitoring Sequence
trans-unit.target: Traffic Manager Monitoring Sequence

trans-unit.source: **Figure 1** – Monitoring sequence example.
trans-unit.target: **Figure 1** – Monitoring sequence example.

trans-unit.source: The numbers in the diagram correspond to the numbered explanation below.
trans-unit.target: The numbers in the diagram correspond to the numbered explanation below.

trans-unit.source: **GET** – The Traffic Manager monitoring system performs a GET on the path and file you specified in the monitoring settings.
trans-unit.target: **GET** – The Traffic Manager monitoring system performs a GET on the path and file you specified in the monitoring settings.

trans-unit.source: **200 OK** – The monitoring system expects an HTTP 200 OK message back within 10 seconds.
trans-unit.target: **200 OK** – The monitoring system expects an HTTP 200 OK message back within 10 seconds.

trans-unit.source: When it receives this response, it assumes that the cloud service is available.
trans-unit.target: When it receives this response, it assumes that the cloud service is available.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Traffic Manager only considers an endpoint to be Online if the return message is a 200 OK.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Traffic Manager only considers an endpoint to be Online if the return message is a 200 OK.

trans-unit.source: If a non-200 response is received, it will assume the endpoint is not available and will count this as a failed check.
trans-unit.target: If a non-200 response is received, it will assume the endpoint is not available and will count this as a failed check.

trans-unit.source: More details about troubleshooting failed checks see [Troubleshooting degraded status on Azure Traffic Manager](traffic-manager-troubleshooting-degraded.md).
trans-unit.target: More details about troubleshooting failed checks see [Troubleshooting degraded status on Azure Traffic Manager](traffic-manager-troubleshooting-degraded.md).

trans-unit.source: **30 seconds between checks** – This check will be performed every 30 seconds.
trans-unit.target: **30 seconds between checks** – This check will be performed every 30 seconds.

trans-unit.source: **Cloud service unavailable** – The cloud service becomes unavailable.
trans-unit.target: **Cloud service unavailable** – The cloud service becomes unavailable.

trans-unit.source: Traffic Manager will not know until the next monitor check.
trans-unit.target: Traffic Manager will not know until the next monitor check.

trans-unit.source: **Attempts to access monitoring file (4 tries)** – The monitoring system performs a GET, but does not receive a response in 10 seconds or less.
trans-unit.target: **Attempts to access monitoring file (4 tries)** – The monitoring system performs a GET, but does not receive a response in 10 seconds or less.

trans-unit.source: It then performs three more tries at 30 second intervals.
trans-unit.target: It then performs three more tries at 30 second intervals.

trans-unit.source: This means that at most, it takes approximately 1.5 minutes for the monitoring system to detect when a service becomes unavailable.
trans-unit.target: This means that at most, it takes approximately 1.5 minutes for the monitoring system to detect when a service becomes unavailable.

trans-unit.source: If one of the tries is successful, then the number of tries is reset.
trans-unit.target: If one of the tries is successful, then the number of tries is reset.

trans-unit.source: Although not shown in the diagram, if the 200 OK message(s) come back more than 10 seconds after the GET, the monitoring system will still count this as a failed check.
trans-unit.target: Although not shown in the diagram, if the 200 OK message(s) come back more than 10 seconds after the GET, the monitoring system will still count this as a failed check.

trans-unit.source: **Marked degraded** – After the fourth failure in a row, the monitoring system will mark the unavailable cloud service as Degraded.
trans-unit.target: **Marked degraded** – After the fourth failure in a row, the monitoring system will mark the unavailable cloud service as Degraded.

trans-unit.source: **Traffic to cloud service decreases** – Traffic may continue to flow to the unavailable cloud service.
trans-unit.target: **Traffic to cloud service decreases** – Traffic may continue to flow to the unavailable cloud service.

trans-unit.source: Clients will experience failures because the service is unavailable.
trans-unit.target: Clients will experience failures because the service is unavailable.

trans-unit.source: Clients and secondary DNS servers have cached the DNS record for the IP address of the unavailable cloud service.
trans-unit.target: Clients and secondary DNS servers have cached the DNS record for the IP address of the unavailable cloud service.

trans-unit.source: They continue to resolve the DNS name of the company domain to the IP address of the service.
trans-unit.target: They continue to resolve the DNS name of the company domain to the IP address of the service.

trans-unit.source: In addition, secondary DNS servers may still hand out the DNS information of the unavailable service.
trans-unit.target: In addition, secondary DNS servers may still hand out the DNS information of the unavailable service.

trans-unit.source: As clients and secondary DNS servers are updated, traffic to the IP address of the unavailable service will slow.
trans-unit.target: As clients and secondary DNS servers are updated, traffic to the IP address of the unavailable service will slow.

trans-unit.source: The monitoring system continues to perform checks at 30 second intervals.
trans-unit.target: The monitoring system continues to perform checks at 30 second intervals.

trans-unit.source: In this example, the service does not respond and remains unavailable.
trans-unit.target: In this example, the service does not respond and remains unavailable.

trans-unit.source: **Traffic to cloud service stops** – By this time, most DNS servers and clients should be updated and traffic to the unavailable service stops.
trans-unit.target: **Traffic to cloud service stops** – By this time, most DNS servers and clients should be updated and traffic to the unavailable service stops.

trans-unit.source: The maximum amount time before traffic completely stops is dependent on the TTL time.
trans-unit.target: The maximum amount time before traffic completely stops is dependent on the TTL time.

trans-unit.source: The default DNS TTL is 300 seconds (5 minutes).
trans-unit.target: The default DNS TTL is 300 seconds (5 minutes).

trans-unit.source: Using this value, clients stop using the service after 5 minutes.
trans-unit.target: Using this value, clients stop using the service after 5 minutes.

trans-unit.source: The monitoring system continues to perform checks at 30 second intervals and the cloud service does not respond.
trans-unit.target: The monitoring system continues to perform checks at 30 second intervals and the cloud service does not respond.

trans-unit.source: **Cloud service comes back online and receives traffic** – The service becomes available, but Traffic Manager does not know until the monitoring system performs a check.
trans-unit.target: **Cloud service comes back online and receives traffic** – The service becomes available, but Traffic Manager does not know until the monitoring system performs a check.

trans-unit.source: **Traffic to service resumes** - Traffic Manager sends a GET and receives a 200 OK in under 10 seconds.
trans-unit.target: **Traffic to service resumes** - Traffic Manager sends a GET and receives a 200 OK in under 10 seconds.

trans-unit.source: It then begins to hand out the cloud service’s DNS name to DNS servers as they request updates.
trans-unit.target: It then begins to hand out the cloud service’s DNS name to DNS servers as they request updates.

trans-unit.source: As a result, traffic starts to flow to the service once again.
trans-unit.target: As a result, traffic starts to flow to the service once again.

trans-unit.source: Child and parent endpoint status for nested profiles
trans-unit.target: Child and parent endpoint status for nested profiles

trans-unit.source: The following table describes the behavior of Traffic Manager monitoring for child and parent profiles of a nested profile and the minChildEndpoints setting.
trans-unit.target: The following table describes the behavior of Traffic Manager monitoring for child and parent profiles of a nested profile and the minChildEndpoints setting.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [What is Traffic Manager?](traffic-manager-overview.md).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [What is Traffic Manager?](traffic-manager-overview.md).

trans-unit.source: Child Profile Monitor status
trans-unit.target: Child Profile Monitor status

trans-unit.source: Parent Endpoint Monitor status
trans-unit.target: Parent Endpoint Monitor status

trans-unit.source: Notes
trans-unit.target: Notes

trans-unit.source: DisabledThis is due to the profile being disabled by you.
trans-unit.target: DisabledThis is due to the profile being disabled by you.

trans-unit.source: Stopped
trans-unit.target: Stopped

trans-unit.source: The parent endpoint state is Stopped, not Disabled.
trans-unit.target: The parent endpoint state is Stopped, not Disabled.

trans-unit.source: The Disabled state is reserved for indicating that you have disabled the endpoint in the parent profile.
trans-unit.target: The Disabled state is reserved for indicating that you have disabled the endpoint in the parent profile.

trans-unit.source: DegradedAt least one is child endpoint is in a Degraded state.
trans-unit.target: DegradedAt least one is child endpoint is in a Degraded state.

trans-unit.source: Online state, if the number of Online endpoints in the child profile is at least the value of minChildEndpoints.CheckingEndpoint state, if the number of Online plus CheckingEndpoint endpoints in the child profile is at least the value of minChildEndpoints.Otherwise, in the Degraded state.
trans-unit.target: Online state, if the number of Online endpoints in the child profile is at least the value of minChildEndpoints.CheckingEndpoint state, if the number of Online plus CheckingEndpoint endpoints in the child profile is at least the value of minChildEndpoints.Otherwise, in the Degraded state.

trans-unit.source: Traffic is routed to an endpoint of status CheckingEndpoint.If minChildEndpoints is set too high, the parent endpoint will always be degraded.
trans-unit.target: Traffic is routed to an endpoint of status CheckingEndpoint.If minChildEndpoints is set too high, the parent endpoint will always be degraded.

trans-unit.source: OnlineAt least one child is an Online state and none are in the Degraded state.
trans-unit.target: OnlineAt least one child is an Online state and none are in the Degraded state.

trans-unit.source: Same as above.
trans-unit.target: Same as above.

trans-unit.source: CheckingEndpointsAt least one is ‘CheckingEndpoint’; none are ‘Online’ or ‘Degraded’
trans-unit.target: CheckingEndpointsAt least one is ‘CheckingEndpoint’; none are ‘Online’ or ‘Degraded’

trans-unit.source: Same as above.
trans-unit.target: Same as above.

trans-unit.source: InactiveAll endpoints are either Disabled or Stopped, or this is a profile with no endpoints
trans-unit.target: InactiveAll endpoints are either Disabled or Stopped, or this is a profile with no endpoints

trans-unit.source: Stopped
trans-unit.target: Stopped

trans-unit.source: To configure monitoring for a specific path and file name
trans-unit.target: To configure monitoring for a specific path and file name

trans-unit.source: Create a file with the same name on each endpoint you plan to include in your profile.
trans-unit.target: Create a file with the same name on each endpoint you plan to include in your profile.

trans-unit.source: For each endpoint, use a web browser to test access to the file.
trans-unit.target: For each endpoint, use a web browser to test access to the file.

trans-unit.source: The URL consists of the domain name of the specific endpoint (the cloud service or website), the path to the file, and the file name.
trans-unit.target: The URL consists of the domain name of the specific endpoint (the cloud service or website), the path to the file, and the file name.

trans-unit.source: In the Management Portal, under **Monitoring Settings**, in the **Relative Path and File Name** field, specify the path and file name.
trans-unit.target: In the Management Portal, under **Monitoring Settings**, in the **Relative Path and File Name** field, specify the path and file name.

trans-unit.source: When you are finished making your configuration changes, click **Save** at the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: When you are finished making your configuration changes, click **Save** at the bottom of the page.
